articles.author: mmcfalljohnsen@businessinsider.com (Morgan McFall-Johnsen), Morgan McFall-Johnsen
articles.title: How the 'failed' quarantine of the Diamond Princess cruise ship started with 10 coronavirus cases and ended with more than 630
articles.description: Kim Kyung-Hoon/Reuters The Diamond Princess cruise ship went from 10 cases of the new coronavirus to more than 630 over the course of its two-week quarantine. Experts and officials have criticized the decision to keep people on the ship and poor hygiene pract…
articles.content:
Passengers on the Diamond Princess cruise ship got their first piece of bad news on February 4: Ten people onboard had tested positive for the novel coronavirus.
It was the beginning of a two-week ordeal of quarantine orders and disease response that has bee… [+1008 chars]

articles.author: Akin Oyedele
articles.title: 'This bubble will likely collapse': JPMorgan sounds the alarm on a hugely popular trade that's twice as overstretched as it was before the dot-com crash
articles.description: The valuation gap between value and low-volatility stocks has grown twice as large as it was during the height of the dot-com boom. This trend has created an unsustainable "equity factor bubble" that is likely to burst, according to Marko Kolanovic, JPMorgan'…
articles.content:
It is still a tough time to be an investor whose preoccupation is finding cheap stocks.
Value investors, as they're called, caught a break last year when their factor returned to favor amid an underperformance streak that had largely been in place since 2007… [+2728 chars]

articles.author: Marley Jay
articles.title: GOLDMAN SACHS: Buy these 12 stocks to keep crushing the market as profit margins shrink

articles.content:
A surprise can be a welcome distraction, and David Kostin — the chief US equity strategist for Goldman Sachs — says a little bit of good news over the last few weeks may have papered over a lot of worry.
Fourth-quarter earnings were better than expected over… [+1894 chars]

articles.author: Isobel Asher Hamilton
articles.title: Huawei is downplaying coronavirus impact on its smartphone sales, but experts say it will suffer more than Apple
articles.description: The novel coronavirus has been a disaster for companies relying on China for supply chain and customers, with firms including Apple, Foxconn, AP Moller-Maersk, Air France-KLM all issuing warnings. Chinese smartphone giant Huawei has been coy on coronavirus im…
articles.content:
The outbreak of the coronavirus has dented the smartphone industry, with Apple warning that it expected a hit to revenues thanks to factory shutdowns and store closures.
Samsung, the world's biggest phone maker, is currently less affected since about half it… [+3847 chars]

articles.author: Linette Lopez
articles.title: Wall Street has a new slogan for why stocks keep going up as the world falls apart: 'Nothing Matters'
articles.description: The mantra on Wall Street these days is "nothing matters." It seems no matter how huge the event — a debilitating virus ravaging China, the rise of Bernie Sanders — none of it matters. Stocks just go up, and in credit markets good debt trades close to junk. C…
articles.content:
Business Insider
For the last few weeks one phrase has encapsulated the energy on Wall Street. It's very simple: "Nothing matters."
The phrase has become a catchall for a host of oddities that are making investors distrust the market. In this market investm… [+5750 chars]
